bcl:text.#text:
means a corporation that
          is
a company within the meaning of the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
designated as an emergency communications corporation under section 2 of
            this Act;

bcl:text.#text: means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Royal Canadian Mounted Police,

bcl:text.#text:
an organization operating a police force or police department providing police
            services to the public, including a municipal police board under the ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
an organization operating a fire department providing fire protection services
            to the public,

bcl:text.#text: British Columbia Emergency Health Services under the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other organization designated by regulation;

bcl:text.#text:
means an agreement in relation to an emergency
          communications corporation, or a corporation that proposes to become an emergency
          communications corporation, between parties who are or intend to become members of the
          corporation or between the corporation and one or more of those parties;
includes the City of Vancouver.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The minister may, by order, designate a corporation as an emergency communications
        corporation if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the purposes of the corporation are those required or permitted under section 3,
          and

the minister has reviewed and approved the members' agreement for the
          corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An emergency communications corporation must have as its primary purpose the
          provision of emergency communications and related services to its members.
An emergency communications corporation may have as additional purposes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the provision of communications and related services, for public safety and
            public service, to municipalities, regional districts, the Provincial government, the
            federal government, government agencies and emergency services agencies, whether or not
            they are members, and

any other purposes prescribed by regulation under section 14 (2) (b) for the
            corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting who may be a member of an emergency communications corporation,
          municipalities, regional districts, emergency services agencies and the Provincial
          government may enter into agreements for membership in an emergency communications
          corporation.

As limits on the authority of a municipality or regional district under subsection
          (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the council or board must enter into a members' agreement by bylaw,
            and

in the case of a regional district, it must have the authority under
            establishing bylaw or letters patent to provide the service to which its membership
            relates.

bcl:text.#text:
A municipality or regional district may become a member of an emergency
          communications corporation without the approval of the Inspector of Municipalities or
          without authorization by regulation, and sections 185  of the  and 265 
          of the  do not apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The members' agreement of an emergency communications corporation may only be
          amended with the approval of the minister and in accordance with that
          agreement.

bcl:text.#text:
Section 154 (2) of the  do not apply
          to an emergency communications corporation.

Despite section 136 (1) of the , the directors of an emergency communications corporation are
          responsible for supervising the general management of the business and affairs of the
          emergency communications corporation.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, provide that additional
          provisions of the  do not apply
          to a specified emergency communications corporation, subject to any alternative
          requirements, restrictions or conditions established by the regulation.

The memorandum, notice of articles and articles of an emergency communications
          corporation may only be amended with the approval of the minister and in accordance with
          the .

Within 60 days after the annual general meeting of an emergency communications
          corporation, the corporation must provide to the minister a copy of its annual financial
          statement under section 198 of the  and the auditor's report on that financial
          statement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Corporation must hold transferred radio licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to the applicable federal legislation, a member of an emergency
          communications corporation must assign or transfer to the emergency communications
          corporation all licences and authorities for radio spectra held by the member that are
          related to the services that the corporation provides to the member.

Subject to the applicable federal legislation, an emergency communications
          corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
must acquire and hold the licences or authorities for radio spectra assigned or
            transferred under subsection (1), and
must manage and allocate the use of those spectra.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
Members of an emergency communications corporation must pay to the corporation all
        rates for operating expenses and capital expenditures that are assessed by the
        corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An emergency communications corporation may only borrow money required

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
for capital purposes related to the purposes of the corporation required or
            permitted under section 3, or

to meet its current operating expenses before its revenue, from all sources, to
            pay for those expenses has been received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Municipal Finance Authority of British Columbia may provide financing to an
          emergency communications corporation for borrowing authorized under subsection (1).

bcl:text.#text:
For the purposes of financing under subsection (2), the , except section 24, applies to an emergency
          communications corporation as if it were a regional district, except that no loan
          authorization bylaw or security issuing bylaw of the corporation is required for the
          borrowing.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Freedom of Information
              and Protection of Privacy Act

bcl:text.#text:
For the purposes of the , the records of an emergency
          communications corporation relating to any services provided to a member of the
          corporation are deemed to be the records of that member.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy
          Act

bcl:text.#text:
An emergency communications corporation must provide a member with copies of
          records of the member under subsection (1), in order to allow the member to comply
          with the .

bcl:link.in:doc:
Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy
              Act

bcl:text.#text:
If subsection (2) applies in relation to a record, a person does not have a
          right of access under the  to the record as being in the custody or under the control of
          the emergency communications corporation and, despite that Act, the person has that right
          only through written request to the member to whom the copy is to be provided under
            subsection
            (2).

bcl:link.in:doc:
Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy
              Act

bcl:text.#text:
Despite the , a person does not have a right of access under that Act to a
          record of, or in the custody or under the control of, an emergency communications
          corporation that relates to services provided by the corporation to the Royal Canadian
          Mounted Police.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Freedom of Information
              and Protection of Privacy Act

bcl:text.#text:
A members' agreement for an emergency communications corporation is void to the
          extent of any conflict between the agreement and the  as it applies under this
          section.

In this section,  means the
          following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an emergency communications corporation;

a current or former member of an emergency communications
            corporation;

a current or former director, employee or agent of an emergency communications
            corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
No action lies and no proceedings may be brought against a protected person, and a
          protected person is not liable for any loss or damages suffered by any person, in relation
          to anything done or omitted to be done by the protected person in relation to the
          provision of or failure to provide emergency communications services by an emergency
          communications corporation.

As an exception, the immunity from legal action otherwise provided to a person by
            subsection
            (2) does not apply if the person has been guilty of malice or wilful
          misconduct in relation to the subject matter of the action.

bcl:text.#text:
The establishment of an emergency communications corporation is to be considered a
          successorship for the purposes of section 35 of the  and the Labour Relations Board has the authority provided by
          that section to determine any matters related to the successorship including, without
          limiting this, the authority to determine the question of trade union
          representation.

A representation vote under the  respecting a matter referred to in subsection (1)
          must be conducted in a manner that the Labour Relations Board considers fair and
          reasonable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2), the Labour Relations Board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
may allow all employees that the Board considers will likely be affected within
            a reasonable time period by the successorship to participate in the vote, whether or not
            those employees have transferred to the emergency communications corporation by the date
            of the vote, and

in order to provide alternative bargaining agent choices to the employees
            entitled to vote, may permit trade unions affected by the successorship to establish a
            new trade union in order to be placed on the ballot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers this necessary in the public
          interest, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make any order in relation to an
          emergency communications corporation that the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers
          appropriate.

Without limiting subsection (1), an order under that subsection may
          provide that a resolution or other decision of an emergency communications corporation is
          void to the extent provided in the order, and may make other provisions in place of those
          declared void.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Conflicts with this Act or a regulation or order under this
        Act

bcl:text.#text:
If there is a conflict between this Act or a regulation under this Act and a
          provision of the , this Act or
          the regulation under this Act prevails.

bcl:text: If there is a conflict between

the provision of the memorandum, notice of articles, articles or agreement is
          deemed to be amended to the extent necessary to comply with this Act or the regulation or
          order.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act or a regulation or order under this Act, and

a provision of the memorandum, notice of articles or articles of an emergency
            communications corporation or a provision of a members' agreement for an emergency
            communications corporation,

bcl:text.#text:
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41
          of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
          make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
designating an organization as an emergency services agency for the purposes of
            section 1;

authorizing an additional purpose for an emergency communications corporation as
            referred to in section 3 (2) (b);

providing for the transition or transfer of pension rights for persons becoming
            employees of an emergency communications corporation.
